newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai planes evacuate 700 from Phnom Penh to Bangkok.
newsitem.headline: Thai planes evacuate 700 from Phnom Penh to Bangkok.

text.p: Six Thai Air Force planes arrived in Bangkok from Cambodia on Tuesday carrying 700 people, mainly Thais and some foreigners who fled fighting in Phnom Penh.
The C-130s had flown to Phnom Penh's battered airport at various times earlier on Tuesday to pick up stranded foreigners in the Cambodian capital.
More military planes would fly out later on Tuesday to ferry another 358 American, Dutch, Japanese and Australian nationals from Phnom Penh to Bangkok.
They were among several hundred people who had waited at Phnom Penh's airport on Tuesday to escape the Cambodian capital after three days of fighting and turmoil.
Those who emerged from the first plane to arrive were seen wearing yellow ribbons on their wrists as identification tags.
Immigration officials at Bangkok airport set up special tables to swiftly clear the evacuees.
Americans among the group of evacuees arriving told U.S. embassy officials at the airport that the safety of foreign nationals and U.S. nationals should now be a major cause for concern.
"There are a lot of Americans in Phnom Penh who want to get out. I personally know of other Americans," Cecil Hill, 50, told embassy officials.

"You should be concerned with other U.S. citizens in Cambodia. The information is not flowing as it should. I am very embarrassed to be an American. The Thais were very helpful but we got virtually nothing from the Americans," he added.
"I'm sorry to leave Cambodia. I had a major investment there. My students deserved something better," said Hill, who owns an English language school in the capital.

A rapid deterioration of conditions in Phnom Penh over the weekend may have caused breakdowns in the warden system, a personal network set up by the U.S. embassy to contact its nationals, evacuees said.

"I think the Americans tried to contact their citizens through the warden system but there were problems in Phnom Penh and my wife is Thai so I was able to get out," said Michael Sheinkman, 39, another American working for an aid oganisation in Cambodia.
Another American, Steve Heder, 45, a professor in the University of London's School of Oriental and African Studies, said he had little help from the U.S. embassy in Phnom Penh.
"I got out completely through the Thai embassy. I think the number of Americans in Phnom Penh was such that a major effort was not necessary. But I can't say that for sure," he said.
"There was room available on the seventh sortie and they made that extra space available to people from other countries," he said.

"I think Hun Sen has a monopoly of power in the centre but he is also more unpopular than he's ever been. I don't think he will be able to keep a lid on the situation without a high degree of caution," said Heder.
